awd_titl_txt: EAGER: PAN-VARIANT COVID-19 DIFFERENTIATED BIOSENSING USING GRAPHENE FIELD-EFFECT SENSORS
awd_abstract_narration:
EAGER: PAN-VARIANT COVID-19 DIFFERENTIATED BIOSENSING USING GRAPHENE FIELD-EFFECT SENSORS



Nontechnical:
The pandemic due to COVID-19 has triggered an increasing demand for scientific research into portable fast biosensors capable of rapid infectious disease detection. With the rise of variants beyond the original COVID-19 strain, there is a need for the scientific understanding and development of biosensors that can be rapidly adapted to sense existing, emerging and new variants of the virus. This award will investigate facile, precise, multiplexed biosensors for detection of the virus from the different evolving variants based on advanced nanomaterials, namely, functionalized graphene field-effect transistors that has the potential for unprecedented sensitivity and a fast response time in a low-cost platform.


Technical:
This research aims to pioneer a single platform for rapid multi-variant detection based on functionalized graphene-antibody selective interaction that affords a high intrinsic limit of detection. Different variants of Covid-19 will be evaluated with the antibody-functionalized graphene field-effect sensing platform. The outcomes of this research will generate new knowledge on multi-variant biosensing, limits of detection, and cross-reactivity through structural and conceptual engineering. The sensor platform is sufficiently versatile to be adapted to detect both existing, emerging, and future variants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This research effort has developed a fast and highly sensitive device solution for rapidly and accurately detecting both COVID-19 and influenza. By using graphene field-effect transistors (GFETs), the investigate team developed a biosensor capable of simultaneously distinguishing between the two viruses, even when present in extremely low concentrations. This sensor addresses critical challenges in rapid diagnostics by providing results in seconds, far faster than traditional methods like polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests, which can take hours. The novel design, featuring a quadruple GFET array, allows for precise and simultaneous detection of multiple viral surface proteins, minimizing cross-reactivity. The high sensitivity is due to the very large surface to volume ratio of monolayer graphene enabling giant sensitivity to environmental charge perturbations. The rapid detection owes in part to the high speed properties of electrons in graphene ensuring the fast communication of any disturbance. This technology offers significant promise for faster, more accessible diagnostics during pandemics and flu seasons, potentially easing the burden on healthcare systems​.

 

Broader Impact

The broader impacts align strongly with the broader impact criteria of NSF. The investigated biosensor technology has the potential to significantly enhance public health by providing a rapid, low-cost, and scalable diagnostic tool that can be deployed in high-population settings, such as hospitals, clinics, and community testing sites. The ability to quickly differentiate between COVID-19 and influenza, which present similar symptoms but require different treatments, will improve patient outcomes and resource allocation in healthcare systems. Furthermore, the versatility of the biosensor means it could be adapted to detect other pathogens, making it valuable for future pandemic preparedness and the control of seasonal viral outbreaks. The research also fosters interdisciplinary collaboration between fields like nanotechnology, electrical engineering, and biology, while offering educational opportunities in these emerging areas. Additionally, the technology could contribute to reducing healthcare disparities by enabling more widespread access to efficient diagnostic tools, especially in resource-limited settings.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2024
Modified by: Deji Akinwande
